confusion_pairs.title: Qualitative vs Quantitative risk analysis

a.definition: Uses categories (low/medium/high) to compare likelihood and impact for prioritization.

b.definition: Uses numeric estimates (often dollars) like SLE/ALE to compare expected loss and justify spending.

bullets: Qualitative is faster and communication-friendly; quantitative is more numeric but still estimate-driven.
Qualitative output is a ranked list/heat map; quantitative output is expected loss (e.g., $/year).
Both are only as good as their assumptions—document inputs either way.

confusion_pairs.title: Likelihood vs Impact

a.definition: How probable/frequent an event is within a time window (or expected frequency like ARO).

b.definition: How much damage happens if the event occurs (CIA, cost, safety, legal, reputation).

bullets: Likelihood answers 'How often?'; impact answers 'How bad?'.
Rare-but-catastrophic can outrank frequent-but-low-impact.
Treat likelihood as evidence-based, not vibes (history, exposure, intel, controls).

confusion_pairs.title: Inherent vs Residual risk

a.definition: Risk level before controls are applied (baseline exposure).

b.definition: Risk that remains after controls/mitigations are in place.

bullets: Inherent = before controls; residual = after controls.
Residual is never zero in real systems; it’s what you accept, transfer, or continue to reduce.
Risk exceptions should describe residual risk, owner, scope, and expiry.

confusion_pairs.title: Risk appetite vs Tolerance vs Threshold

a.definition: Appetite is overall willingness to accept risk; tolerance is acceptable variation within objectives.

b.definition: A specific trigger point that forces action or escalation.

bullets: Appetite is strategic; thresholds are operational triggers.
Tolerance is the 'wiggle room' around goals; thresholds convert that into measurable rules.
Without thresholds, appetite statements become untestable slogans.

confusion_pairs.title: RTO vs RPO

a.definition: Maximum acceptable downtime; how quickly service must be restored.

b.definition: Maximum acceptable data loss window measured in time; how far back you can roll data.

bullets: RTO = restore time; RPO = data loss window.
Low RPO usually requires frequent replication/backups; low RTO requires fast failover.
BIA defines these targets; DRP implements how you meet them.

confusion_pairs.title: MTBF vs MTTR

a.definition: Mean Time Between Failures—rough measure of reliability (time between outages).

b.definition: Mean Time To Repair/Recover—rough measure of how quickly you restore after failure.

bullets: MTBF = reliability; MTTR = recoverability.
Reducing MTTR often boosts availability even if MTBF is unchanged.
Redundancy can improve MTBF-like behavior, but only if failover is tested.

confusion_pairs.title: BIA vs DRP

a.definition: Identifies critical functions and impact of disruption; sets recovery priorities and targets (RTO/RPO).

b.definition: The operational plan to restore IT systems/data after a disaster; executes recovery objectives.

bullets: BIA defines what matters and targets; DRP defines how to restore.
BIA is business-first; DRP is recovery execution (people + process + tech).
If DRP isn’t tested, your BIA targets are wishful thinking.

confusion_pairs.title: Anonymization vs Pseudonymization vs Tokenization

a.definition: Transforms data so re-identification is impractical (no usable link back to individuals).

b.definition: Replaces identifiers (pseudonyms) or values (tokens) but keeps a re-link path via a key or vault mapping.

bullets: Anonymization aims for no re-link; pseudo/token keep a re-link mechanism.
Pseudo/token data is still sensitive because re-identification is possible with the key/vault.
Use tokenization when you need reversibility for operations; anonymize when you don’t.

confusion_pairs.title: Hashing vs Encryption (privacy context)

a.definition: One-way transformation; useful for integrity and sometimes for protecting secrets with salts/slow hashes.

b.definition: Reversible transformation using a key; protects confidentiality for data at rest/in transit.

bullets: Hashing is one-way; encryption is reversible with a key.
Hashing PII doesn’t automatically make it safe—lookups/inference can still re-identify.
Use encryption for confidentiality; use hashing for integrity and safe secret storage (with salt/slow hashing).

confusion_pairs.title: Business vs Government data classification

a.definition: Org-defined labels (public/private/confidential/restricted/etc.) mapped to handling rules.

b.definition: Legal/regulatory classification levels (unclassified/confidential/secret/top secret) with strict handling requirements.

bullets: Business labels vary by org; government labels are typically standardized and legally enforced.
Don’t assume a 1:1 mapping between the two systems.
Whatever the label, it must map to concrete controls (access, encryption, retention).

pet.anonymization.rule: Anonymization aims to prevent re-identification; do it carefully or it fails.

pet.data_masking.micro_example: Mask to last 4 digits in logs; encrypt the full value in storage.

pet.deidentification.rule: Pseudonymization/de-identification reduces direct identifiers but can still be re-linked.

pet.hashing.rule: Hashing is one-way; salt/slow hashing is needed to resist lookup attacks.
pet.hashing.micro_example: Salt passwords to defeat rainbow tables; don’t treat hashed PII as 'anonymous' by default.

pet.obfuscation.rule: Masking/obfuscation reduce exposure in UI/logs but don’t equal encryption.
pet.obfuscation.micro_example: Mask to last 4 digits in logs; encrypt the full value in storage.

pet.overview.rule: PETs reduce exposure by transforming data (minimize identifiability/linkability).
pet.overview.micro_example: Tokenize sensitive values so analytics doesn’t need raw data.

pet.pseudonymization.rule: Pseudonymization/de-identification reduces direct identifiers but can still be re-linked.
pet.pseudonymization.micro_example: Replace customer IDs with pseudonyms; protect the re-link key strongly.

pet.rainbow_table_attack.rule: Rainbow tables crack unsalted/weak hashes using precomputed lookups.
pet.rainbow_table_attack.micro_example: Salting + slow hashing makes rainbow tables far less effective.

pet.tokenization.rule: Tokenization replaces sensitive values with tokens stored via secure vault mapping.
pet.tokenization.micro_example: Store card numbers in a vault; applications use tokens.
